headline: Donostia Throughout History
text:
The best way of adapting to a new country and a new culture is learning about it's most important events. In this sample timeline we are going to cover some of the most important events of Donostia's history, and explain their relevance to the city's culture. Some of the events have a big relevance, because they have turned out in important cultural festivities, and some others are important to understand the origins of Donostia

.

headline: Medieval and Early HistoryFoundation of the City
text:
To know about the beginings of Donostia, we have to turn back to 12th Century, the time where the city was founded

San Sebastián was officially founded by King Sancho VI of Navarre. It was granted a fuero (municipal charter) to attract settlers and develop trade.

headline: Incorporation into Castile
text: The city, along with the province of Gipuzkoa, was annexed by the Kingdom of Castile, shifting its allegiance from Navarre.

headline: San Sebastián Opens the Gates to the New World
text: The city allowed to transport goods to and from the New World. As a result, San Sebastián grew into an important port city, gaining wealth and a stronger role in international trade.

headline: The Fires that Shaped San Sebastián
text: In 1489, 1522, and 1545, San Sebastián was hit by a series of devastating fires that destroyed large parts of the city. These disasters led to major rebuilding efforts, the street San Martin was a result of the rebuilding process incentivated by the King Fernando The Catholic. This was a shift toward using more fire-resistant materials in architecture, changing the city's look and structure forever.

headline: Occupation by French Force
text: In January 1719, France had the perfect pretext to declare war on Spain after a plot to overthrow the French regent, Philippe, Duke of Orleans, was uncovered. In total, around 1200 men fighted to deffend the city . Women also had an important role, helping the soldiers. After occupation, San Sebastían functioned as its strategic coastal role.
mediaCaption: Map of the city of Donostia in 1719 after the French occupation

headline: Destruction and Fire During the Peninsular War
text: After defeating Soult's counter-offensive through the Pyrenees at Sorauren, the town had withstood an assault in July. However, more intense assault began on 26 August, and 31. Despite natural and human-made defenses, the town was captured, and the devastating fire spread throughout the whole town with many people dying, only the street named after that day 31 de Agosto survived. Today, people commemorate that dreadful day with silence and carry candles annually.

headline: First royal visit in San Sebastián
text: Francisco de Paula, brother of the King Fernando VII and his wife Luisa Carlotta, sister of the Queen Maria Cristina. After their visit, other important royals visited the city, including the Queen Maria Cristina who had a huge impact on the city

headline: Demolition of the City Walls
text: This event marked the beginning of modern San Sebastián and the urban expansion. Nowadays it is posible to see the limits of the wall marked in the floor of Boulevard . It is a detail that goes unnoticed by most people, but it shows part of San Sebastián's history.
mediaCaption: Donostia when the Demolitio of the City Walls happened

headline: Inauguration of Kursaal and Victoria Eugenia Theatre
text: Cultural development flourished, and San Sebastián became a center of Belle Époque architecture and leisure. The city is also called "tiny Paris" due to it's resemblance and influence of parisian architecture.
mediaCaption: Poster for the San Sebastián Kursal with an illustration of people from the bélé époque

headline: Spanish Civil War
text:
San Sebastián initially fell under Republican control, but was soon taken by Francoist troops. It started years of political repression. After the Spanish Civil War, It started a 40 years dictatorship, under Francisco Franco's control. Among other prohibitions, he imposed a ban on teaching languages ​​from other territories of the State other than Spanish. Thus, during the 40 years of the dictatorship, speaking Basque was prohibited, and even more so, teaching classes in it.

Although repression continued unabated during the final years of the dictatorship, some Ikastolas were legalized and allowed to teach Basque. Specifically, in San Sebastián, the first Ikastola was established in 1970. However, during the dictatorship, speaking Basque was completely prohibited, and during the final years (including the final days) of the Franco regime, repression against movements defending the identity of Basque culture was total.
mediaCaption: Image of Republican citizens being taken to be shot by soldiers from the Francoist side

headline: Inauguration of San Sebastián International Film Festival
text: In July 1955, San Sebastián hosted its second International Film Festival, focusing on colour films. Despite its ambition, the event faced significant issues: organizational problems, jury disagreements, and rule violations, such as screening films without subtitles and awarding previously released movies. These controversies led the FIAPF to withdraw its official recognition, marking a challenging moment in the festival's history.
mediaCaption: Audrey Hepburn in San Sebastián's International Film Festival

headline: Jazzaldia Inauguration
text: It is known for being one of the most important Jazz festivals in Europe , where artists from the whole world come to play. It is celabrated in the third week of July, and a huge scenery is placed in the Zurriola Beach
mediaCaption: Saxophonists playing, Kursaal in the backround

headline: Basque Nationalism and ETA activity
text: During this decade, the city experienced the tensions of Basque separatism and acts of violence tied to ETA during Spain's transition to democracy.
mediaCaption: The first public manifestation against ETA

headline: Launch of San Sebastián International Film Festival
text: Although it was founded in 1953, the festival gained global recognition by the 1990s, establishing the city as cultural hub. Actors, movie directors and people from all around the world come to the city during this time of the year.
mediaCaption: Robert Mitchum receiving the Premio Donostia 1993

headline: New Kursaal Congress Center Opens
text: Designed by architect Rafael Moneo, the new Kursaal symbolizes the cultural renaissance of San Sebastián.
mediaCaption: Landscape of San Sebastián, Kursaal on the bottom left

headline: European Capital of Culture
text: San Sebastián was named the European Capital of Culture, recognizing its strong identity, cultural diversity, and civic initiatives.
